co.cask.cdap.api.dataset.table

Interface OrderedTable

  • All Superinterfaces:
    AutoCloseable, Closeable, Dataset

    public interface OrderedTable
extends Dataset
    Provides generic table dataset interface.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static String PROPERTY_READLESS_INCREMENT
      Property set to configure read-less increment support for a dataset.
      static String PROPERTY_TTL
      Property set to configure time-to-live on data within this dataset.

      Reads values of all columns in the specified row NOTE: depending on the implementation of this interface and use-case, calling this method may be much less efficient than calling same method with columns as parameters because it may always require round trip to persistent store

      Reads the value of the specified column in the specified row.

      • Methods inherited from interface java.io.Closeable

        close

    • Field Detail

      • PROPERTY_TTL

        static final String PROPERTY_TTL
        Property set to configure time-to-live on data within this dataset. The value given is in milliseconds. Once a cell's data has surpassed the given value in age, the cell's data will no longer be visible and may be garbage collected.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • PROPERTY_READLESS_INCREMENT

        static final String PROPERTY_READLESS_INCREMENT
        Property set to configure read-less increment support for a dataset. When not set, calling the Table.increment(byte[], byte[], long) method will result in a normal read-modify-write operation.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • get

        Map<byte[],byte[]> get(byte[] row,
                     byte[][] columns)
                       throws Exception
        Reads the values of the specified columns in the specified row.

        NOTE: objects that are passed in parameters can be re-used by underlying implementation and present in returned data structures from this method.

        Returns:
        map of columns to values, never null
        Throws:
        Exception

      • get

        Map<byte[],byte[]> get(byte[] row)
                       throws Exception
        Reads values of all columns in the specified row NOTE: depending on the implementation of this interface and use-case, calling this method may be much less efficient than calling same method with columns as parameters because it may always require round trip to persistent store

        NOTE: objects that are passed in parameters can be re-used by underlying implementation and present in returned data structures from this method.

        Parameters:
        row - row to read from
        Returns:
        map of columns to values, never null
        Throws:
        Exception

      • get

        byte[] get(byte[] row,
         byte[] column)
           throws Exception
        Reads the value of the specified column in the specified row.
        Parameters:
        row - row to read from
        column - column to read value for
        Returns:
        value of the column or null if value is absent
        Throws:
        Exception

      • get

        Map<byte[],byte[]> get(byte[] row,
                     byte[] startColumn,
                     byte[] stopColumn,
                     int limit)
                       throws Exception
        Reads the values of all columns in the specified row that are between the specified start (inclusive) and stop (exclusive) columns.

        NOTE: objects that are passed in parameters can be re-used by underlying implementation and present in returned data structures from this method.

        Parameters:
        startColumn - beginning of range of columns, inclusive
        stopColumn - end of range of columns, exclusive
        limit - maximum number of columns to return
        Returns:
        map of columns to values, never null
        Throws:
        Exception

      • put

        void put(byte[] row,
       byte[][] columns,
       byte[][] values)
         throws Exception
        Writes the specified values for the specified columns for the specified row. NOTE: depending on the implementation this may work faster than calling put(byte[], byte[], byte[]) multiple times (esp. in transaction that changes a lot of rows)
        Parameters:
        row - row to write to
        columns - columns to write to
        values - array of values to write (same order as values)
        Throws:
        Exception

      • put

        void put(byte[] row,
       byte[] column,
       byte[] value)
         throws Exception
        Writes the specified value for the specified column for the specified row.
        Parameters:
        row - row to write to
        column - column to write to
        value - to write
        Throws:
        Exception

      • delete

        void delete(byte[] row)
            throws Exception
        Deletes all columns of the specified row. NOTE: depending on the implementation of this interface and use-case, calling this method may be much less efficient than calling same method with columns as parameters because it may always require round trip to persistent store
        Parameters:
        row - row to delete
        Throws:
        Exception

      • delete

        void delete(byte[] row,
          byte[] column)
            throws Exception
        Deletes specified column of the specified row.
        Parameters:
        row - row to delete from
        column - column name to delete
        Throws:
        Exception

      • delete

        void delete(byte[] row,
          byte[][] columns)
            throws Exception
        Deletes specified columns of the specified row. NOTE: depending on the implementation this may work faster than calling delete(byte[], byte[]) multiple times (esp. in transaction that changes a lot of rows)
        Parameters:
        row - row to delete from
        columns - names of columns to delete
        Throws:
        Exception

      • incrementAndGet

        long incrementAndGet(byte[] row,
                   byte[] column,
                   long amount)
                     throws Exception
        Increments (atomically) the specified row and columns by the specified amounts.
        Parameters:
        row - row which values to increment
        column - column to increment
        amount - amount to increment by
        Returns:
        new value of the column
        Throws:
        Exception

      • incrementAndGet

        Map<byte[],Long> incrementAndGet(byte[] row,
                               byte[][] columns,
                               long[] amounts)
                                 throws Exception
        Increments (atomically) the specified row and columns by the specified amounts.

        NOTE: depending on the implementation this may work faster than calling incrementAndGet(byte[], byte[], long) multiple times (esp. in transaction that changes a lot of rows).

        NOTE: objects that are passed in parameters can be re-used by underlying implementation and present in returned data structures from this method.

        Parameters:
        row - row which values to increment
        columns - columns to increment
        amounts - amounts to increment columns by (same order as columns)
        Returns:
        map of values of counters after the increments are performed, never null
        Throws:
        Exception

      • increment

        void increment(byte[] row,
             byte[] column,
             long amount)
               throws Exception
        Increments (atomically) the specified row and columns by the specified amounts, without returning the new value.
        Parameters:
        row - row which values to increment
        column - column to increment
        amount - amount to increment by
        Throws:
        Exception

      • increment

        void increment(byte[] row,
             byte[][] columns,
             long[] amounts)
               throws Exception
        Increments (atomically) the specified row and columns by the specified amounts, without returning the new values. NOTE: depending on the implementation this may work faster than calling increment(byte[], byte[], long) multiple times (esp. in transaction that changes a lot of rows)
        Parameters:
        row - row which values to increment
        columns - columns to increment
        amounts - amounts to increment columns by (same order as columns)
        Throws:
        Exception

      • compareAndSwap

        boolean compareAndSwap(byte[] row,
                     byte[] column,
                     byte[] expectedValue,
                     byte[] newValue)
                       throws Exception
        Compares-and-swaps (atomically) the value of the specified row and column by looking for the specified expected value and if found, replacing with the specified new value.
        Parameters:
        row - row to modify
        column - column to change
        expectedValue - expected value before change
        newValue - value to set
        Returns:
        true if compare and swap succeeded, false otherwise (stored value is different from expected)
        Throws:
        Exception

      • scan

        Scanner scan(byte[] startRow,
           byte[] stopRow)
             throws Exception
        Scans table.
        Parameters:
        startRow - start row inclusive. null means start from first row of the table
        stopRow - stop row exclusive. null means scan all rows to the end of the table
        Returns:
        instance of Scanner
        Throws:
        Exception

      • getSplits

        List<Split> getSplits(int numSplits,
                    byte[] startRow,
                    byte[] stopRow)
                      throws Exception
        Gets splits of range of rows of the table.
        Parameters:
        numSplits - number of splits to return
        startRow - start row of the range, inclusive
        stopRow - stop row of the range, exclusive
        Returns:
        list of Splits
        Throws:
        Exception
